comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Title needs amending to Australian Eleven Hotel. It was on Elizabeth Street at the NE corner with Kettle Street, across the street from Redfern Park. See www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/6662642331/sizes/o/ Grid 10D - it was still there in 1928, so this is not a demolition photo. Mrs Laura Creamer was landlady in the late 1880s - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/28355508 - and from the crossed-out sign, it looks like she had recently been replaced. I am not sure how to look up licencees, bu the date must be c.1890 like several of these 4481 photos with vignetting at the corners. I wonder what the story behind this photo is?

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Google maps Street View - g.co/maps/q5atz

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content:
Australian Eleven Hotel, John L. Kettle, 157-159 Elizabeth Street, Redfern. - 1888 Sands.
Australian Eleven Hotel, Don McDonald, 169 Elizabeth Street, Redfern. - 1918 Sands.

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: At the Licensing Court on Tuesday 7th January 1890, the license for the Australian Eleven Hotel was transferred from John Lewis Kettle to Edwin Berry. - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13755547

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: Here we go - the license was previously transferred from Laura Creamer to John Kettle at the Licensing Court session of Tuesday 22nd March 1887. - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13629948

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Does anyone understand the street numbering of Elizabeth Street, Redfern?  Has it changed since these photos?  (Yes, obviously!).

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] I bet you could find an old map shewing ye olde street numbering. Obviously the street numbering used to start again when it left the city and hit Redfern. I wonder if they changed the numbering to avoid the kind of confusion that happens today along Oxford Street (the numbering starts again in each suburb).

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Ha! I found one map dated 1886, but it does not have street numbering. It shows the Australian XI Hotel a little north of Kettle Street, with room for the skittle alley and quoits. www.nla.gov.au/apps/cdview?pi=nla.map-f671-sd&rgn=0.4... The tramway didn't arrive in that part of Elizabeth St until about 1900. The sewerage building was under way in 1888, but I don't see any connection with these buildings (or the Kent St ones). A bit of a mystery?

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] The street numbering changed after Redfern was absorbed by Sydney City Council in 1949. Redfern was later combined in 1968 with other municipalities to form Northcott Municipal Council, later re-named the South Sydney Municipal Council. - www.cityofsydney.nsw.gov.au/aboutsydney/historyandarchive...

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Thanks! I just found out that in the old numbering No.3 Elizabeth Street, Redfern, was on the NE corner with James St. ie the numbering started at Cleveland Street and ran south, odd numbers on the east of Elizabeth Street. This should mean that Old No.3 is equivalent to New No. 520. If you then add 517 to the Old Nos., you should get the equivalent New Nos. But alas, it doesn't work for the second row panorama above - there are no recognisable buildings at (205 + 517 =) 722 Elizabeth Street (in Waterloo) - Google Maps Street view - g.co/maps/x3rdx

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] The Victorian Filigree terraces at 520-550 Elizabeth Street, Redfern, were originally numbered from No. 1. No. 49 was at the next intersection with Cooper. "No. 520 (formerly No. 1), a tiny terrace on an oddly shaped block, was demolished and an extension to No. 522 (now known as 520-522) built in its place." - www.heritage.nsw.gov.au/07_subnav_04_2.cfm?itemid=2420148

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] I found the maps! To see the start of Elizabeth Street in the old street numbering system, between James and Cooper Streets (1-49), go here: library.sl.nsw.gov.au/record=b2281363 - click Redfern - and see thumbnail 8 (Redfern Sheet No. 5, 2nd ed., 1892 map). See thumbnail 7 for the less detailed 1887 1st ed. survey map. Then see thumbnail 10 for Elizabeth Street from Cooper to Redfern Streets (51-119) (Redfern Sheet No. 6., 2nd ed.,1893 map). I'll post the rest as I find them. Maps are fully zoomable. Yipee!

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] See thumbnail 24 for Elizabeth Street from Redfern to Phillip Streets (121-243) (Redfern Sheet No. 13., 2nd ed., 1893 map). Click on the map below to be taken to the zoomable map: See the 1st ed. 1887 map here - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/_zoomify/2008/D00663/a1367380.html It's interesting to compare the two maps and see the new buildings and the rear extensions along the strip over the intervening 5-6 years. The Australian Eleven Hotel is no. 159. This map also ties in exactly with the second row panorama. No. 205 is the small house to the left in the photo (right on the map) of the terrace with those odd four bay awnings. In fact this map encompasses the entire known panorama from W. Jennings Furniture Removalist at No. 133 to the Chemist at No. 225. It would seem we are missing 1 photo between the M. Glynn Produce Store photo and the Australian Eleven Hotel photo, and a sequence of about 5 photos between the Australian Eleven Hotel photo and the one of No. 205. [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw] I wonder ... could the photographs have been taken to supplement the 1887 cartographic survey of Redfern? We already know the sequence is likely date shortly after March 1887 (not c.1890, as Kettle would have been unlikely to leave Creamer's name on his pub awning for 3 years!).

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Simply brilliant work!   Hit for a six in the first innings!

I find this series particularly fascinating as there is no trace left of any of these buildings,  except the photos and maps.  Several blocks were obliterated in the late 1950s.  Redfern Park would have been much more attractive with this line of shops, hotels and houses facing it.

And I think there is something unusual or experimental about the lens the photographer used.  The verandahs appear distorted or enlarged and at odd angles,  like through a fish-eye.  No idea what the technical term for this is.

comment.author: 83019400@N05
comment._content: My Grandmother with her husband William Smith were the licencee for a short time of this Hotel 1922/23. Does anyone have any information on that time of the hotel. 13021936
